trans-unit.source: How to use blob storage from PHP | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use blob storage from PHP | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure blob service to upload, list, download, and delete blobs. Code samples are written in PHP.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure blob service to upload, list, download, and delete blobs. Code samples are written in PHP.

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure blob service.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure blob service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in PHP and use the <linkText>Azure SDK for PHP[download]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in PHP and use the <linkText>Azure SDK for PHP[download]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include uploading, listing, downloading, and deleting blobs.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include uploading, listing, downloading, and deleting blobs.

trans-unit.source: For more information on blobs, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on blobs, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: The only requirement for creating a PHP application that accesses the Azure blob service is the referencing of classes in the Azure SDK for PHP from within your code.
trans-unit.target: The only requirement for creating a PHP application that accesses the Azure blob service is the referencing of classes in the Azure SDK for PHP from within your code.

trans-unit.source: You can use any development tools to create your application, including Notepad.
trans-unit.target: You can use any development tools to create your application, including Notepad.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, you use service features, which can be called within a PHP application locally or in code running within an Azure web role, worker role, or website.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, you use service features, which can be called within a PHP application locally or in code running within an Azure web role, worker role, or website.

trans-unit.source: To use the Azure blob service APIs, you need to:
trans-unit.target: To use the Azure blob service APIs, you need to:

trans-unit.source: Reference the autoloader file using the <linkText>require_once[require_once]</linkText><title></title> statement, and
trans-unit.target: Reference the autoloader file using the <linkText>require_once[require_once]</linkText><title></title> statement, and

trans-unit.source: Reference any classes you might use.
trans-unit.target: Reference any classes you might use.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to include the autoloader file and reference the ServicesBuilder class.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to include the autoloader file and reference the ServicesBuilder class.

trans-unit.source: This example (and other examples in this article) assume you have installed the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer.
trans-unit.target: This example (and other examples in this article) assume you have installed the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer.

trans-unit.source: If you installed the libraries manually or as a PEAR package, you need to reference the WindowsAzure.php autoloader file.
trans-unit.target: If you installed the libraries manually or as a PEAR package, you need to reference the WindowsAzure.php autoloader file.

trans-unit.source: In the examples below, the require_once statement will be shown always, but only the classes necessary for the example to execute are referenced.
trans-unit.target: In the examples below, the require_once statement will be shown always, but only the classes necessary for the example to execute are referenced.

trans-unit.source: To instantiate an Azure blob service client, you must first have a valid connection string.
trans-unit.target: To instantiate an Azure blob service client, you must first have a valid connection string.

trans-unit.source: The format for the blob service connection string is:
trans-unit.target: The format for the blob service connection string is:

trans-unit.source: For accessing a live service:
trans-unit.target: For accessing a live service:

trans-unit.source: For accessing the storage emulator:
trans-unit.target: For accessing the storage emulator:

trans-unit.source: To create any Azure service client, you need to use the ServicesBuilder class.
trans-unit.target: To create any Azure service client, you need to use the ServicesBuilder class.

trans-unit.source: You can:
trans-unit.target: You can:

trans-unit.source: Pass the connection string directly to it or
trans-unit.target: Pass the connection string directly to it or

trans-unit.source: Use the CloudConfigurationManager (CCM) to check multiple external sources for the connection string:
trans-unit.target: Use the CloudConfigurationManager (CCM) to check multiple external sources for the connection string:

trans-unit.source: By default, it comes with support for one external source - environmental variables.
trans-unit.target: By default, it comes with support for one external source - environmental variables.

trans-unit.source: You can add new sources by extending the ConnectionStringSource class.
trans-unit.target: You can add new sources by extending the ConnectionStringSource class.

trans-unit.source: For the examples outlined here, the connection string will be passed directly.
trans-unit.target: For the examples outlined here, the connection string will be passed directly.

trans-unit.source: A BlobRestProxy object lets you create a blob container with the createContainer method.
trans-unit.target: A BlobRestProxy object lets you create a blob container with the createContainer method.

trans-unit.source: When creating a container, you can set options on the container, but doing so is not required.
trans-unit.target: When creating a container, you can set options on the container, but doing so is not required.

trans-unit.source: (The example below shows how to set the container access control list (ACL) and container metadata.)
trans-unit.target: (The example below shows how to set the container access control list (ACL) and container metadata.)

trans-unit.source: Calling setPublicAccess(PublicAccessType::CONTAINER\_AND\_BLOBS) makes the container and blob data accessible via anonymous requests.
trans-unit.target: Calling setPublicAccess(PublicAccessType::CONTAINER\_AND\_BLOBS) makes the container and blob data accessible via anonymous requests.

trans-unit.source: Calling setPublicAccess(PublicAccessType::BLOBS_ONLY) makes only blob data accessible via anonymous requests.
trans-unit.target: Calling setPublicAccess(PublicAccessType::BLOBS_ONLY) makes only blob data accessible via anonymous requests.

trans-unit.source: For more information about container ACLs, see <linkText>Set container ACL (REST API)[container-acl]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about container ACLs, see <linkText>Set container ACL (REST API)[container-acl]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Blob service error codes, see <linkText>Blob Service Error Codes[error-codes]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Blob service error codes, see <linkText>Blob Service Error Codes[error-codes]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To upload a file as a blob, use the BlobRestProxy->createBlockBlob method.
trans-unit.target: To upload a file as a blob, use the BlobRestProxy->createBlockBlob method.

trans-unit.source: This operation creates the blob if it doesn't exist, or overwrites it if it does.
trans-unit.target: This operation creates the blob if it doesn't exist, or overwrites it if it does.

trans-unit.source: The code example below assumes that the container has already been created and uses <linkText>fopen[fopen]</linkText><title></title> to open the file as a stream.
trans-unit.target: The code example below assumes that the container has already been created and uses <linkText>fopen[fopen]</linkText><title></title> to open the file as a stream.

trans-unit.source: Note that the previous sample uploads a blob as a stream.
trans-unit.target: Note that the previous sample uploads a blob as a stream.

trans-unit.source: However, a blob can also be uploaded as a string using, for example, the <linkText>file\_get\_contents[file_get_contents]</linkText><title></title> function.
trans-unit.target: However, a blob can also be uploaded as a string using, for example, the <linkText>file\_get\_contents[file_get_contents]</linkText><title></title> function.

trans-unit.source: To do this using the previous sample, change $content = fopen("c:\myfile.txt", "r"); to $content = file_get_contents("c:\myfile.txt");.
trans-unit.target: To do this using the previous sample, change $content = fopen("c:\myfile.txt", "r"); to $content = file_get_contents("c:\myfile.txt");.

trans-unit.source: To list the blobs in a container, use the BlobRestProxy->listBlobs method with a foreach loop to loop through the result.
trans-unit.target: To list the blobs in a container, use the BlobRestProxy->listBlobs method with a foreach loop to loop through the result.

trans-unit.source: The following code displays the name of each blob as output in a container and displays its URI to the browser.
trans-unit.target: The following code displays the name of each blob as output in a container and displays its URI to the browser.

trans-unit.source: To download a blob, call the BlobRestProxy->getBlob method, then call the getContentStream method on the resulting GetBlobResult object.
trans-unit.target: To download a blob, call the BlobRestProxy->getBlob method, then call the getContentStream method on the resulting GetBlobResult object.

trans-unit.source: Note that the example above gets a blob as a stream resource (the default behavior).
trans-unit.target: Note that the example above gets a blob as a stream resource (the default behavior).

trans-unit.source: However, you can use the <linkText>stream\_get\_contents[stream-get-contents]</linkText><title></title> function to convert the returned stream to a string.
trans-unit.target: However, you can use the <linkText>stream\_get\_contents[stream-get-contents]</linkText><title></title> function to convert the returned stream to a string.

trans-unit.source: To delete a blob, pass the container name and blob name to BlobRestProxy->deleteBlob.
trans-unit.target: To delete a blob, pass the container name and blob name to BlobRestProxy->deleteBlob.

trans-unit.source: Finally, to delete a blob container, pass the container name to BlobRestProxy->deleteContainer.
trans-unit.target: Finally, to delete a blob container, pass the container name to BlobRestProxy->deleteContainer.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of the Azure blob service, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of the Azure blob service, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.

trans-unit.source: See the MSDN reference: <linkText>Azure Storage</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: See the MSDN reference: <linkText>Azure Storage</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Visit the <linkText>Azure Storage team blog</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Visit the <linkText>Azure Storage team blog</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: See the PHP block blob example at <https://github.com/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-for-php-samples/blob/master/storage/BlockBlobExample.php>.
trans-unit.target: See the PHP block blob example at <https://github.com/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-for-php-samples/blob/master/storage/BlockBlobExample.php>.

trans-unit.source: See the PHP page blob example at <https://github.com/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-for-php-samples/blob/master/storage/PageBlobExample.php>
trans-unit.target: See the PHP page blob example at <https://github.com/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-for-php-samples/blob/master/storage/PageBlobExample.php>
